conclusion: Understanding the problem involves a glass sphere with refractive index n and radius R, and a point light source at distance d from the center.
Light rays must not hit the boundary of the sphere at points where they would be reflected back.
Light rays must exit the sphere at points where they do not form an angle greater than the critical angle for total internal reflection.
The critical angle for total internal reflection is given by sin(θc) = 1/n.
For light to exit the sphere without reflection, the angle of incidence must be less than the critical angle.
The light source must be positioned such that the maximum angle of incidence does not exceed the critical angle.
The maximum angle of incidence occurs when the light ray travels along the boundary and forms a right angle with the normal.
The maximum angle of incidence is 90° minus the critical angle.
The distance d from the center to the light source must be such that the angle subtended by the diameter is less than or equal to the critical angle.
The light source must be within a certain distance from the center to ensure all light rays can exit without reflection.
The condition for the position of the light source is d ≤ R√(n² - 1).
